div1.p: In the Circuit Court of the United States
District of Washington Northern Division
In the Matter of the Petition of Char. W Nordstrom for writ of Habeas Corpus vs. Ed. W Cudahee, Sheriff and Respondent
Notice of Appeal
Filed in the U.S. Circuit Court, Dist. of Washington. AUG 8 1901. A Reeves Ayres, Clerk.
HM Matthew Deputy
James Hamilton Lewis, Hardin, and Albertson
In the United States Circuit Court For The State of Washington In the Ninth Judicial Cicuit Holding Terms at Seattle
In the Matter of the Petition of Charles W. Nordstrom for Writ of Habeas Corpus and relief thereon. Notice of Appeal

To the Honorable C.H. Hanford, Judge of the above named Court, to the State of Washington, Honorable Eward Cudahee, Sheriff of the County of King, State of Washington, and Honorable Walter S. Fulton, Prosecuting Attorney for the County of King:

You and each of you will please take notice that the Petitioner Charles W. Nordstrom, here and now appeals this cause in this petition for Habeas Corpus and relief thereon, to the Supreme Court of the United States at the next term thereof holding terms at the City of Washington, and particularly from that announcement at the City of Washington, and particularly from that announcement and judgment of the Honorable Court of the 26 day of July 1901, refusing and denying relief to Petitioner as prayed for. All of which more particulary appears by that memrander of reasons and the written statement of views of the Honorable Court addressed to the Petitioner through his Counsel and filed with the Petition herein as the decision of the Judge upon the same, being of the date of 26 July 1901 and specified the following grounds for said appeal herein, to wit:
I.
That the Court declined to grant relief upon the said petition in any form whatsover, holding that the matters in said Petition was without merit.
II.

That the said Court held that the matters stated in the said petition were wanting in merit, and this without giving to petitioner an opportunity of being heard upon the same or having any day in Court upon the same.
III.

That the Court denied and refused to give petioner a hearing upon application for Habeas Corpus, and that the said Honorable Court such refusal suspend the operation of a Writ of Habeas Corpus when the country is not at war or in state of insurrection.
IV.
Because the Honrable Court declined to make any order allowing the petitioner to verify with facts and sustain with law the matters and things named in the same petition.
V.
For that the Honorable Court refused the petitioner a hearing, declined to hear any form of argument by the petitioner or his Counsel, either of fact or law in the petitioners behalf.
VI.

Because the Honorable Court declined in any wise whatsoever to grant any relief upon the said petition, or to name a time when the said petitioner might be heard in open court and declined to hear the peititoner in any wise whatsoever.
VII.

Because the Honorable Court declined to grant petitioner the Writ of Habeas Corpus, or declined to grant the petitioner an order upon the respondent to show cause why the said writ should not issue, and declined and refused to grant the petitioner any hearing and denied the petitioner any relief under the said petition declining to hear argument by the petitioner or his Counsel as to whether merit in law or in fact was contained in said petition and the facts conseded thereon.
James Hamilton Lewis, Attorney For Petitioner
